questions.value: Have you ever been convicted of a felony?

options.result:
In Alabama, you are eligible to vote.

Register to vote now

questions.value: Have you been convicted of one or more of the following felonies?
questions.extra:
• Aggravated child abuse
  • Aggravated theft by deception
  • Assault (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Attempt to commit an explosives or destructive device or bacteriological or biological weapons crime
  • Bigamy
  • Burglary (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Conspiracy to commit an explosives or destructive device or bacteriological or biological weapons crime
  • Dissemination or public display of obscene matter containing visual depiction of persons under 17 years of age involved in obscene acts
  • Distribution, possession with intent to distribute, production of, or offer or agreement to distribute or produce obscene material
  • Electronic solicitation of a child
  • Endangering the water supply
  • Enticing a child to enter a vehicle for immoral purposes
  • Facilitating solicitation of unlawful sexual conduct with a child
  • Facilitating the online solicitation of a child
  • Facilitating the travel of a child for an unlawful sex act
  • Forgery (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Hindrance or obstruction during detection, disarming, or destruction of a destructive device or weapon
  • Hindering prosecution of terrorism
  • Human trafficking (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Incest
  • Kidnapping (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Manslaughter
  • Murder (including noncapital, reckless, and felony murder)
  • Parents or guardians permitting children to engage in production of obscene matter
  • Possession or possession with intent to disseminate of obscene matter containing visual depiction of persons under 17 years of age involved in obscene acts
  • Possession, manufacture, transport, or distribution of a destructive device or bacteriological or biological weapon
  • Possession, manufacture, transport, or distribution of a detonator, explosive, poison, or hoax device
  • Possession or distribution of a hoax device represented as a destructive device or weapon
  • Production of obscene matter containing visual depiction of persons under 17 years of age involved in obscene acts
  • Production or distribution of a destructive device or weapon intended to cause injury or destruction
  • Prohibited acts in the offer, sale, or purchase of securities
  • Rape (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Robbery (1st, 2nd, or 3rd degree)
  • Selling, furnishing, giving away, delivering, or distribution of a destructive device, a bacteriological weapon, or biological weapon to a person who is less than 21 years of age
  • Sexual abuse (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Sexual abuse of a child under 12 years old
  • Sexual torture
  • Sodomy (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Soliciting or providing support for an act of terrorism
  • Terrorism
  • Theft of lost property (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Theft of property (1st or 2nd degree)
  • Theft of trademarks or trade secrets
  • Torture or other willful maltreatment of a child under the age of 18 (Child Abuse)
  • Trafficking in cannabis, cocaine, or other illegal drugs or trafficking in amphetamine or methamphetamine
  • Traveling to meet a child for an unlawful sex act
  • Treason
  • Or any other felony involving Moral Turpitude?

options.result:
In Alabama, you are eligible to vote.

Register to vote now

options.value: I was convicted in federal court or outside of Alabama
options.result: Under Alabama law, convictions in other states or in federal court only take away the right to vote if they would constitute one of above offenses had they been convictions in Alabama state court.

questions.value: Have you been convicted of one or more of the following felonies?

options.result:
You may be able to restore your right to vote by seeking a pardon from the Board of Pardons and Paroles.
To request a pardon, you can complete this form and submit it to the Alabama Board of Pardons and Paroles.

questions.value: Have you completed your sentence including probation and or parole?

options.result: Unfortunately you are not yet eligible to restore your voting rights. You will be eligible once you complete your sentence and pay all fines, fees and restitution that you owe.

questions.value: Do you owe any outstanding fines, fees, or restitution from your conviction of one of the above felonies?

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are currently ineligible to restore your voting rights. You are ineligible to restore your right to vote until you have paid off your fines, fees, and restitution or the Board of Pardons and Paroles has forgiven them.
You can request a reduction or forgiveness of your fines by filling out this form and submitting it to the Alabama Board of Pardons and Paroles.

questions.value: Do you have any pending felony charges?

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are currently ineligible to restore your voting rights. You are ineligible to restore your right to vote until you have paid off your fines, fees, and restitution or the Board of Pardons and Paroles has forgiven them.
You can request a reduction or forgiveness of your fines by filling out this form and submitting it to the Alabama Board of Pardons and Paroles.

You are eligible to restore your voting rights. If you complete a request for a Certificate of Eligibility to Register to Vote(CERV) and submit it to the Alabama Board of Pardons and Paroles, the state must restore your right to vote. The state should respond to your request within 44 days.

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Individuals who have been convicted of felonies of moral turputide are eligible to vote only upon completion of their sentence, including probation and parole.

Common felonies of moral turpitude include:
  • Murder
  • Manslaughter
  • Assault
  • Sexual assault
  • Sexual abuse of a minor
  • Robbery
  • Arson
  • Burglary
  • Theft
  • Forgery
  • Endangering the welfare of a minor
  • Riot
  • Criminal mischef
  • Misconduct involving a controlled substance
  • Distribution or possession of child pornography
NOTE: This is not a complete list of felonies of moral turpitude. If you are unsure if your conviction qualifies as a felony of moral turpitude, call or have a friend or family member call 1-866-OUR-VOTE for assistance.

In Alaska, you are eligible to vote.

Register to vote now

questions.value: Are you currently incarcerated, on probation, or parole for a felony?

options.result: Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now.

You must have completed your sentence, including payment of all Legal Financial Obligations (LFOs), and submitted the required paperwork to restore your rights. Please visit the official Arkansas state website for more details and instructions on how to restore your voting rights:

Restore your rights here

questions.value: Were you convicted of one of the following?
questions.extra:
• Treason
  • Bribery in an election
  • A violent offense
  • Any offense under KRS Chapter 507
  • Any assault
  • Strangulation in the first degree
  • Human trafficking
  • Any felony conviction in another state or in the federal system

options.result:
Unfortunately, automatic restoration of your voting rights is not available for these crimes. You can apply for clemency or restoration through the governor's office. For more information, visit the Kentucky Civil Rights Restoration page:

Restore your rights

questions.value: Was your felony conviction out of state or a federal conviction?

options.result:

Restore your rights

In Kentucky, you are eligible to vote, provided all other requirements are met.

In Mississippi, you are eligible to vote.

Only individuals convicted of one of 23 specific felony crimes lose the right to vote:

  • Arson
  • Armed robbery
  • Bigamy
  • Bribery
  • Embezzlement
  • Extortion
  • Felony bad check
  • Felony shoplifting
  • Forgery
  • Larceny
  • Murder
  • Manslaughter
  • Obtaining money or goods under false pretense
  • Perjury
  • Rape
  • Receiving stolen property
  • Robbery
  • Theft
  • Timber larceny
  • Unlawful taking of motor vehicle
  • Statutory rape
  • Carjacking
  • Larceny under lease or rental agreement

Register to vote now

questions.value: Were you convicted of one of the following crimes: murder, manslaughter, rape, bribery, theft, arson, obtaining money or goods under false pretense, perjury, forgery, embezzlement, or bigamy?

options.result: Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Your right to vote can only be restored through a bill passed by both houses of the legislature or through the Governor. Note that in Mississippi, your voting rights are not automatically restored after completing probation or parole.

In Mississippi, you are eligible to vote.

In South Dakota, you are eligible to vote.

Register to vote now

questions.value: Were you convicted of a non-violent felony?

options.result: If you have completed your sentence for a non-violent felony in Wyoming, you may be eligible for automatic restoration of voting rights, depending on the time period and jurisdiction. Please verify your status or visit the Wyoming Secretary of State website for more information on how to restore your rights.

questions.value: Were you convicted of a violent felony?

options.result: In Wyoming, if you were convicted of a violent felony, your voting rights may be restored automatically after five years post-sentence completion, including probation or parole. However, automatic restoration is not guaranteed. Please contact the Wyoming Secretary of State or visit the Wyoming Secretary of State website for further guidance on restoring your rights.

In Wyoming, you are eligible to vote.

Register to vote now

questions.value: Have you received clemency for your felony conviction?

options.result: If you have received clemency, your voting rights may be restored. Please confirm your status with the Wyoming Secretary of State or visit the Wyoming Secretary of State website for more information.

If your rights have not been restored through clemency or automatic restoration, you are not eligible to vote. Please visit the Wyoming Secretary of State website for more details on the restoration process.
